metadata.title: Google Data Studio: 5 Charts for Visualizing your Data | by Matt Przybyla | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Google Data Studio: 5 Charts for Visualizing your Data
metadata.description: This article is a part of a series on a tutorial of everything Google Data Studio (GDS) [1]. The first article of this series can be found here [2]. As the second part of the GDS series, this…

all_paragraphs: This article is a part of a series on a tutorial of everything Google Data Studio (GDS) [1]. The first article of this series can be found here [2]. As the second part of the GDS series, this tutorial will go over specific types of visualizations. With each chart, there are dimensions, metrics, sort, date range, interactions, and style menus that are changeable. In addition to these charts, there is the text you can add, as well as data and filter controls. The dataset below that is used for this tutorial and chart highlight has a filter control to display certain categories over others. The date range filter, also consisting of a drop-down menu, is useful if you want to zoom in or out of your data. The best part of these features is that when you edit a filter in the dashboard view, the data is, therefore, adjusted as well with its respective charts.

The dataset is dummy data created in a Google Sheet. It was developed to mimic similar fields of the coronavirus pandemic dataset of 2020. The fields include the date, region, record counts, and dummy categories. When following this tutorial, a different dataset, such as the real coronavirus dataset [3] can be used for educational and academic research purposes only.

The treemap chart is an excellent way of visualizing the space of your dimension. Best used for categorical data, the chart works by increasing or decreasing the amount of its size of the metric of your choice. For example, the chart below describes not only the most impactful categories of the data in terms of size, but also adds a heatmap layer that aides in emphasizing certain categories. Another useful feature of this chart is that, once you are in dashboard mode, the data used in the treemap can be downloaded in a variety of ways.

The stacked combo chart is useful in that it combines both the popular bar chart, with a line chart layered over. If you want to describe two similar metrics while layering over a line for emphasis, this chart works well. In addition to the multilayered method, the data can be described by hovering over the specific date range.

While the pie chart may seem old news, in GDS, the amount of specification is seemingly endless. For example, for the metric chosen to be charted, the sort method, which is used in most charts in GDS, different aggregations can be displayed. Some of the aggregations include sum, average, count, count distinct, min, max, median, standard deviation, and variance. Once a sort is chosen, you can either decide to descend or ascend your data. In the pie chart below, I chose to use only one color gradient, but you can easily switch to multicolored for a different effect.

In GDS, there are actually 3 sub facets of the general pivot table: pivot table, pivot table with bars, and the pivot table with heatmap. Using your dimension as the index and the date range as the column, the metrics will be the values where the min and max values are colored in heatmap form to show the importance of your metric (this effect is somewhat similar to conditional formatting in Excel, but can display gradients).

The smoothed line chart is typically used for displaying time series, but I wanted to show how categorical data could be expressed. In the chart below, the regions (US states) are on the X-axis, while the value of the metric is the Y-axis, with all metrics charted to their respective colors. I believe this chart is one of the best GDS has to offer because it can show a variety of information from your data. Below, you can see both categorical and numeric data all while compared to one another.

GDS has plenty of different visualizations to describe your data and metrics. They prove to be a useful method of showing off your exploratory data analytics, while also for displaying your ad-hoc data science metrics. This tutorial is a part of a series on GDS, please comment below you have any questions or specialized requests for further articles in this series.

My Google Data Studio dashboard was created using a dummy dataset. The features/fields/columns are dummy attributes as well. The images are my own screenshots of the GDS dashboard. The data and metrics visualized in my dashboard screenshots are to not be used for any medical reason. It is static, non-real, and does not have any reliance on accuracy. It was purely developed for tutorial purposes.
